stops.narrative: Hey there Explorer. My name’s Scrib. I’m an Ecpantheria scribonia, but most non-Latin speakers know me as a leopard moth. My species, in our larval form, are big fans of fine dining, especially on the flowers of Magnolia stellata, or magnolia trees. Adults, like me, feed on nectar from most flowering plants. Springtime is prime time for my favorite meal to bloom. This past spring, however, has been super cold...hello winter number two. This means that the magnolias haven’t been able to bloom as gloriously. I need you to help me find some lush magnolias please! Keep in mind, I eat other plants too, maybe you can help me find ones with flowers. My friend Piña the Pinecone is also out here somewhere. Maybe we’ll cross paths with her. Start off your exploration by venturing to the Winter Garden. Good luck!

stops.hint: Start off your exploration by venturing into the Winter Garden.
stops.fact: Did you know… The Pieris part of this plant’s name is the name of the home of the Greek Muses

stops.narrative: Hey Explorer, congrats on your first plant find! These flowers are tiny but accompanied by mighty, fiery leaves. You think I can reach the nectar?

stops.hint: Your next stop is going to be near a neat little pond, head to the Japanese Maples.
stops.fact: Did you know... The latter part of the name of this tree, palmatum, was named after the palms of hands, since they look similar to the shape of the leaves

stops.narrative: These maples are so colorful! There’s tons of versions with all sorts of leaf colors. Looks like there’s no flowers for me, though…

stops.hint: Your next stop is going to be near a neat little pond, head to the Japanese Maples.
stops.fact: Did you know... These are technically azaleas, but they're part of the larger plant family of rhododendron.

stops.narrative: Finally, some more food. These flowers are royally gorgeous! They’re native to Korea, they even have a festival dedicated to them.

stops.hint: Your next stop is also going to be another native Korean plant, you’ll find it in the Asiatic Maples section
stops.fact: Did you know… The Pieris part of this plant’s name is the name of the home of the Greek Muses.

stops.narrative: Not one, not two, but three flowers clustered together on this fine maple specimen! Yum.

stops.hint: The next stop on your radar is also going to be a flowering tree my favorite one at that. Next stop, Magnolias!
stops.fact: Did you know…  Magnolias, as a species, are ancient. Beetles were the first insects to pollinate them.

stops.narrative: You did it, Explorer! You found a magnolia tree! Thankfully, the flowers are in bloom and made it through the harsh winter and it looks like not many of them were frost damaged. This is going to be a feast for my species. It’s a feast for your eyes too. Look out for Piña next!

Hey there Explorer. I’m Piña the Pinecone, of the tree Pinus rigida, or the pitch pine. My family of trees has undergone a vicious attack from red turpentine beetles. Because of the drier summers, we couldn’t keep up with the lack of water reaching us. The beetles ate through our bark to reach our phloem, and the trees could not handle all the stress. Since 2005, about 40 of us at the Arboretum have been infested with beetles. Our trunks are sturdy and rigid, the rigida moniker isn’t a lie, but after droughts and beetle attacks, even our mighty bodies are taken down. I need your help. I need you to go through the Arboretum and help me find one of my surviving family members. Along the way, you’ll see lots of other plants. Hopefully, seeing these living, lush plants will encourage you to learn about all of them while they are alive, learn about biodiversity, and what YOU can do to help preserve plants! Start off by heading towards the Giant Sequoias.

stops.hint: Start off by heading towards the Giant Sequoias.
stops.fact: Did you know… Giant sequoias are one of the oldest living species on Earth, with the oldest recorded one being around 3500 years old.

stops.narrative: What a huge specimen! My family doesn’t grow nearly as big. This guy has probably been around longer than most people working at the Arboretum. I wonder what he’s seen…

stops.hint: Your next stop is going to be straight ahead in the Camellia section.
stops.fact: Did you know... Camellias are important symbolic plants in Japan and China. In China, they’re lucky symbols during Chinese New year.

stops.narrative: This variety of the common camellia is so vibrant! It’s always nice to see such a happy bloom when our environment is usually gloomy.

stops.hint: Your next stop is going to be down a nearby staircase, you’ll see some more lovely flowers.
stops.fact: Did you know... These are technically azaleas, but they're part of the larger plant family of rhododendrons.

stops.narrative: These little pink flowers are Washington’s state flower. They’re common along the West Coast, and their cousins, other rhododendrons and azaleas, are common throughout the Arboretum.

stops.hint: Your next stop is along the winding path, just stay straight on. Look out for bright organge flowers.
stops.fact: Did you know… this flower hybrid was developd in the 1950’s in Portland, Oregon.

stops.narrative: Nice job finding this plant, Explorer! It’s a hybrid and beautiful flower.

stops.hint: Your next stop looks like it’s going to be exciting for me! Keep going!
stops.fact: Did you know…The pitch pine grows well in soils that most other plants could not thrive in, like swampy and acidic soil. Our trunks are usually quite twisted and irregular, we grow to our own beat.

stops.narrative: Hey, it’s a family member! I’m so excited to see an elder tree that’s growing healthily. Looks like some of my fellow pinecones are also developing quite well. Thanks so much for all the help. Thanks for all the help, Explorer! All of this Arboretum exploration has hopefully allowed you to learn a lot about the incredible biodiversity that exists here. You can take your knowledge and apply it at home in your community. You can read up about plant care and start your own garden, responsibly planting a variety of lush plants is a great way to add to the biodiversity of your area. You can talk to the lovely folks at the Arboretum about further learning opportunities as well! Visit arboretumfoundation.org for more info.
